cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 30 (Thursday, February 15, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. IVEY:H.R. 7378.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill is enacted pursuant to the power granted toCongress under Article I, Section 8, Clauses 5 and 18 of theUnited States Constitution.The single subject of this legislation is:Federal commendation of a single great American with theminting of an honorary Congressional gold medal.[Page H680]

item.text: Referred to the Committee on Financial Services, and in addition to the Committee on House Administration, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

policyArea.name: Civil Rights and Liberties, Minority Issues
Civil Rights and Liberties, Minority Issues

bill.title: Frederick Douglass Congressional Gold Medal Act

item.title: Frederick Douglass Congressional Gold Medal Act
Frederick Douglass Congressional Gold Medal Act
To award posthumously a Congressional Gold Medal to Frederick Douglass in recognition of his contributions to the cause of freedom, human rights, and the abolition of slavery in the United States.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Committee on Financial Services, and in addition to the Committee on House Administration, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
